title: How People Can Make Smarter—and Healthier—Social-Media Choices
sub_head: Is the problem us or the platforms? Brian Primack, a professor of public health and medicine, says it’s both.
body:
It has become increasingly clear this past year that social media isn’t always healthy for people.
The Wall Street Journal has published multiple investigations into what can go wrong for users. In the Facebook Files, Facebook ’s own research found about one in eight of the app’s users reported engaging in compulsive use of the company’s app that affected their sleep, work, parenting or relationships. On TikTok, the app can drive young users into endless spools of adult content. And on Instagram, many teens—in particular teen girls—experience negative social comparisons that can affect how they view and describe themselves.
